headline: Famous Japanese Restaurant-Style Salad Dressing
description: This Japanese salad dressing has lots of great taste sensations — garlic, ginger, minced celery, ketchup, soy sauce, lemon juice, vinegar, and oil.

video.description: A simple, tangy salad dressing you make in the blender.
video.name: Famous Japanese Restaurant-Style Salad Dressing

name: Famous Japanese Restaurant-Style Salad Dressing

recipeInstructions.text: Combine minced onion, peanut oil, rice vinegar, water, ginger, celery, ketchup, soy sauce, sugar, lemon juice, garlic, salt, and pepper in a blender. Blend until all ingredients are well-pureed, about 30 seconds.

review.reviewBody: Great recipe, just like in the restaurants. Not sure why others are saying not to use peanut oil, it is a key ingredient that keeps it to style with the original. I'm a big believer on adjusting ingredients based on your preferences. Me, I like to add more celery, it just freshens it up. Thanks for sharing
I also used garlic powder onion powder & ground ginger & it was still good...way darker than I thought it would be & was wanting more of the light orange (yum yum sauce) color !
Loved it. Didn't have celery but still tasted great!
Used Swerve in place of sugar, and didn't add the salt as I felt the soy sauce was salty enough. Delicious!
I followed some suggestions by adding sesame oil. I also added less of the rice vinegar and added half of an apple.
Way too acidic, nothing, like the real thing. Proportions seem to be wrong
This is thinner than I remember the Benihana dressing I think this mimics but the flavor is quite good. I cut it in half but otherwise made it exactly as presented. I’ll definitely make it again.

It's nothing like the Japanese steak house dressing I love so much. So I was disappointed. I followed exactly. But it's still an OK ginger dressing. Just don't expect it to taste like that Japanese steak house dressing.
I used a full celery stalk and this turned out perfect! Very good!
5 Stars. I LOVE Japanese dressing at restaurants. Now I have it too! Sooooo good. Very easy to make. I double recipe so that I can splurge

Measurements were perfect only I made some substitutions and everybody just loved it. I used avocado oil, regular white vinegar, braggs amino acids instead of soy, monk sugar adding an extra quarter teaspoon, organic ketchup and no salt

I was looking for something like the hibachi place that I'm familiar with. This definitely had the core flavor. The color was darker, either a result of more ketchup or soy sauce. It was also much more acidic and less spicy. I will probably try less ketchup, less vinegar, and a tad more ginger and see how it turns out. Overall it was good though.

It is not to my liking. Too much Soy sauce.
Doesn't taste anything like my Japanese restaurants dressing.
Only had ginger in a white wine vinegar, so needed a bit more sugar, but wow. Good
Tastes just like the Japanese Restaurant dressing
Almost like ShoGun
I left out celery but otherwise followed instructions. Very very good. Have made it 3 times now in 2 weeks.
Actually better than a restaurant!
Actually better than a restaurant!
Well, I followed recipe to the T...however, it tasted nothing like our local Japanese restaurant dressing. It may be good to some m, and I’m not downing the recipe at all, but it’s not for us.

Great tasting recipe. More or less followed the recipe. Added slightly more ginger and black pepper at the end.

Substituted fresh tomato for ketchup.

Not a well thought out recipe. There is absolutely no reason to waste your time "mincing" all your ingredients before you "puree" them in a blender. A simple chop would suffice and make this recipe far more efficient.
I had to substitute white vinegar for the rice wine vinegar but it was still very tasty. I will make this again!
This dressing was a big hit....it came out great. My husband really enjoyed it and so did I.
loved it
delicious!!!!! Will definitely be making this again
Awesome recipe!
It was too vinegary and I could taste the ketchup. It didn’t taste like Asian salad dressings that I’ve made before from different recipes. No I would not make this again.
Very similar taste, but WHOO! Next time I will cut WAY BACK on the rice vinegar, as it is a very pungent ingredient. Has great potential, just needs a bit of tweaking to get just right.
Verry good. Try straining half of the mixture after blending and add half the onions. I like it to sit in the fridge with shredded carrots before using( 1 hour )
Don't pay attention to the other reviews who complain about this recipe because this recipe tastes excellent and is definitely spot on. It tastes exactly like jasmine's. Will definitely make again.
Awesome, love it. This is the exact Japanese restaurant dressing I was looking for to make eating a green salad a little easier.
didn't have celery replaced with carrot

My wife and I love this kind of dressing on our salads whenever we go to Thai or Japanese restaurants, which is why we were excited to try this recipe out. I made a few modifications because we prefer the nuttier version of this dressing that we’ve had at restaurants by us. 

-Cut the vinegar back to 1/4 cup instead of 1/3
-Completely cut out the ketchup
-Added 1/2 cup of creamy peanut butter
-Added one extra teaspoon of white sugar
-Added one more tablespoon of ginger paste

I didn’t use fresh ginger root, but the ginger paste you can buy in the cold case of the grocery section.
I made no changes it was perfect.
This might not be for everyone but I love the freshness of the garlic, onion, and ginger over a simple salad as a side to an asian inspired meal.
this is a fabulous recipe - I add in cucumber, carrots, bean sprout, cilantro and whatever else may be tasty in it!
We enjoyed this recipe very much. Eyeballed some ingredients but not to far off the original recipe. Turned out great!
This recipes is noted on many internet sites and for good reason, it's wonderful!! Measure ingredients, it's important, for the ideal balance and flavor.
Excellent recipe. Perfect taste. Guests always want the recipe.
This came out amazing!!!!
Excellent. My wife and I loved it. Just make sure not to blend it too long so that it has a thicker consistency. Rookie mistake!

unfortunately i agree with DA174, this had too much onion.. like SVPORTER, i swapped out half the peanut oil for homemade broth.. i should have also swapped out half of the half of peanut oil with sesame b/c i ended up adding sesame oil to try to get the taste right.. i think this would be a good marinade.. but it's just okay on bok choy cole slaw.. bf suggested cilantro to brighten it.. sadly we're all out
Very close to the dressing from our local Japanese restaurant. Next time I'll reduce the soy sauce by at least half. I added juice of an orange and 1 tbsp maple syrup (Canadian!)

Very good recipe and highly recommended! Definitely use a blender. I used the "Bullet" and it liquified the dressing. Thus, made it soupy. Also, I added 2 tablespoon of sugar and it came out very close to our local Japanese restaurant. Next time, I will add an orange instead.

I followed the receipt exactly but I didn't have any peanut oil. So I added a tablespoon of peanut butter and used a quarter cup olive oil. I'm glad I used the peanut butter because I think I would have missed the peanut flavor without the peanut oil. I will defiantly make this again and I will buy some peanut oil so that I can make it as stated.
I made it with no changes and all fresh ingredients. (Except ketchup - that was in a bottle).
Tastes great. I used a few cherry tomatoes instead of ketchup and vegetable oil instead peanut oil bc I didn't have peanut.
This was great! It makes a lot more than I needed but it was nice to have extra! It is a little strong on ginger so I would start with less ginger and add more if necessary!
This wasn't anywhere close to the salad dressing I am used to getting in a Japanese restaurant. I made it twice to make sure I did it right. I had to dump it both times.

It was very good but I wish it had been just a touch sweeter. Next time I will add a bit more sugar. Also, used sesame oil because I had it on hand and I think it made the flavor more authentic like a Japanese steakhouse might be. I will make this again. It took a minute to prepare but was not difficult.
Very very good. I took one reviewers advice and grated a carrot and that was the finishing touch it needed. I only had rice vinegar not rice wine vinegar. I wanted to have 2 salads in a row!

I didn't have any ketchup so I used 1.5 Tbsp of tomato paste. Next time I might add a little less rice wine vinegar to make it less tart. Just my preference. All in all this is a really great tasting, quick and easy recipe.

I love this recipe and have made it twice now. I have yet to find other homemade recipes that beat the jar brands as of yet. The only ginger dressing I like better than this one is the one our favorite Japanese restaurant makes.

I am in love with this dressing! It makes me want to lick the sides of the bowl clean, however I found this recipe had too much ginger in it. I did skip the celery step because I didn't have any on hand so that may affect the spiciness of the ginger, but I know that the next time i make it i will only use one tablespoon of ginger.
Next time, reduce ketchup and onion content, increase celery and ginger
To much onion, it's all I can taste.
Made as written. Delicious.

I love this dressing! What a wonderful blend of ingredients. I didn't have peanut oil, so followed another reviewer's suggestion to use 1/2 olive oil and 1/2 sesame oil. I also used a full stalk of celery, and 1 carrot. Other than that, I followed the recipe exactly. I will definitely make this over and over! Thanks for sharing.
Try katsu sauce instead of ketchup.

I thought this was better than my sushi restaurant serves; so fresh tasting. I made a few changes based on other reviews. I used only 1/4 C. oil, used olive because I didn't have peanut oil. Used only 2 Tbs. onion. Added a pinch of ground celery seed and added 1/4 tsp. sesame oil. I mixed it with my immersion blender. I also used low sodium soy and did not add any additional salt. I'm sure I will make this frequently!

I loved this dressing as is but with the following changes it became a 5 star recipe: I added 1 TBS sesame oil; used low sodium Tamari in place of the soy sauce and did not add any salt; added 1/4 cup shredded carrot; used 1 small tomato and 1/4 tsp tomato paste in place of ketchup. I did not add any water as the dressing was quite fluid - it did not need water. Next time I think I will reduce the white onion and add some green onion.
way too much soy sauce. it tasted nothing like Japanese ginger dressing.

We made this exactly as listed, and the onion flavor was very powerful. The rice wine vinegar was a little too prominent as well. I think if we reduce the onion and increase the celery and add a bit more sugar then it will be great. Great place to start and easy to adjust since it's a simple recipe. I also agree that there is no reason the mince the ingredients (just cut small enough for measurement, the blender will take care of the rest). We used a white onion and all fresh ingredients.
It came out too vinegary and thin.
Easy and delicious!!! I will make it over and over and over........
Perfect. Outstanding flavor, just like my favorite sushi bar
Closest to restaurant's that I've ever made! Sub 1/3 sesame oil for peanut. Add additional tsp ginger.
I love this dressing at the restaurants and love to make it at home!
So good! So glad I'm able to recreate this at home now
I really love this recipe! !! I'm not a big salad eater, solely because i get bored of the dressings. The dressing requires lots of ingredients but that's okay. Love it!
It's really close to the restaurant version. Only I will omit the ketchup next time. Overall, very tasty and very easy!

EXACTLY what I was looking for! No tweaking required on my part whatsoever. I followed this recipe to a T, and it was seriously close to my favorite restaurant version! Just as the recipe stated, I did mince the onion and celery for measuring purposes prior to blending. We will be keeping this one!
I love all the ingredients, exc. ketchup which to me, doesn't seem Asian-like n made it look like thousand Island dressing.

This is a great recipe. Be careful about the onion you use. If you use
a regular white or yellow onion that is hot, it will make or break the
taste of this dressing. Raw onions that are hot will throw a bitter
taste. I make sure I taste the onion first before using it. Try Walla
Walla or Vidalia onions when in season. If not available try green onion
white part only or a leek.
Exactly what I was looking for. I didn't change a thing.
Excellent recipe.
No Subs!!! perfect!! 2 cloves garlic 1 stick celery 1 smallish-med onion!
We love this. The only change we made was to use half the oil to cut down on calories. One of our favorites!
THIS IS SOO GOOD!!
This was amazing. I used fresh ginger. I didn't have lemon juice but that didn't seem to matter. It still turned out great.
This was fantastic! My family loved it. It made a lot and I used it as dressing for several days. I will make it again as a marinade. Great flavor, really happy with this!

Great flavor, easy. We served it with angel hair pasta, shrimp and salad on top. Husband LOVED it. I will use vidalia onion next time, yellow onion is too acidic for me. However, this was truly delicious.
This dressing is better than what is served in Japanese restaurants. I love it and so do my dinner guests.

I absolutely loved this recipe. Followed it nearly to the letter except I left out the Lemon juice as I didn't have any and I used a sweetener substitute instead of sugar (Splenda). This tasted pretty much identical to the dressing I get at my favorite Japanese restaurant. I did as others here suggested and didn't chop up anything, just let my food processor take care of it, but I did mince the ginger root so that I was certain it would incorporate well. My picky husband went crazy for it...great recipe :)
Great Japanese dressing recipe. I LOVE that everything in it is fresh. I used fresh tomato instead of ketchup as AnataniOne suggested and it was GREAT! Thank you!
This was AMAZING my family loved it i will be making this again!
Way too much ketchup

Very good recipe. I made a half recipe for our small family. Like many reviewers I added some sesame seed oil for more asian taste. I agree with the reviewer who said to use fresh ingredients - not canned, dried, powdered, etc. I regret putting in the ketchup. It tasted much fresher without it. I tasted it before realizing I forgot to put it in. Next time I will use a little fresh tomato instead, or just skip it. I also added some grated carrot for extra texture but it was not needed. I threw in chunks of the onion and celery and used the small cup of the magic blender. BTW, if you are making a full recipe, use the larger cup.
I liked the flavor of this, but it didn't taste like the Japanese dressing I'm used to. I'll keep looking. Love that it's quick and easy though.

I've made this recipe as is and it's delicious! I do make changes to it now to try to make it a little healthier for us. Light flavor olive oil instead of peanut, honey instead of sugar, tamari soy sauce. 
Also this last time I made it, I didn't have a few items so had to make more changes.
I used white wine vinegar instead of rice. I also just added more vinegar instead of adding water.
Celery seed instead of celery.
And I used a red onion instead of a white. I think this really helped w/ the flavor some to make it less oniony
Added a bit more sugar as it was quite bitter, a few teaspoons of honey and some mayo. Perfect!

I love this dressing. I decide to try this recipe for a cold noodle salad (soba buckwheat) with julienne cabbage and cucumbers. There is a Restaurant here in JAX that serve it and I love it. With this dressing it get better than the restaurant. Fantastic.

This recipe does need some tweaking, but it really is a winner! I have omitted salt, ketchup, honey, celery and water altogether because they are unnecessary. I used the white part of the green onion because it is milder than regular onion. Go easy on the ginger, a little goes a long way! Do not add salt! You will get plenty of salt content from the miso and sauces. The sweetness will come from the carrot and ginger. Mine came out a nice golden yellow color. Here is my version if you want to give it a try. Just combine all the following ingredients to your food processor until well blended and then refrigerate overnight:

1/2 c. green onion (white part only) - 1 bunch yields appx. 1/4 c.
2 cloves garlic 
2 carrots
Juice of one lemon
1 T. Gari - Japanese pickled ginger
1. T. Tahini - Ground sesame seed paste
2 T. miso soybean paste
2 t. fish sauce
2 t. Ponzu soy sauce - Soy sauce with citrus
1/2 c. peanut oil
1/3 c. rice vinegar
12 turns of pepper mill
Good dressing, but did not taste like the one served at the sushi restaurant near me.

Outstanding and simple recipe. Excellent without modification, perfect if you add just a little shredded carrot in order to give it some extra sugar and texture.

Don't expect miracles with dry, powdered or jarred substitutions. Fresh ginger, fresh garlic and fresh veggies are a must for this. I've made it with peanut, olive and avocado oil (depending on what I had in the cupboard) and it came out great each time. If you do add sesame oil, go light, it's very strongly flavored and anything more than a fractional teaspoon is going to overpower the other flavors.
Came out great! Followed the recipe to a "T" and it was a hit!
This is now our favorite salad dressing. It tastes virtually like the dressing at the nearby Japanese restaurant. We love it.

Tweaked the recipe based on other folks recommendations. Instead of peanut oil did sesame and olive oil mixed, and instead of celery I did carrots. It tasted great fresh, but after an evening in the fridge it tasted JUST like what you get at the restaurants!
